ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Better spoken and non-verbal communication skills
I learned Spanish and practiced it.

My speaking skills greatly improved during this course. I overcame profound discomfort and embarrassment with speaking in Spanish one-on-one and in presentations through the constant teacher-student and student-student interactions.

I developed various Spanish grammar skills involving the future, present, and past. I learned about many various topics about Latin America including Afrolatino visibility, the reappropriation of witches and gitanas, indigenous worldviews, and fake news.
This course really helped me gain confidence in speaking about issues I care about in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was very good in terms of ensuring language learning/acquisition, the workload felt like a lot at times.

There were more weaknesses than strengths to this course. While we practiced Spanish everyday, we were not learning any new grammatical structures effectively enough to become better at Spanish and integrate it into my writing or speaking. Additionally, the course itself is very anti-Indigenous. The movie for the Indigenous unit was framed through a white savior narrative. The materials in the unit was also not telling of any current conditions of Indigenous people that included resistance or happiness or joy. All of the materials focused on the oppressive situation of Indigenous people through anecdotes that did not properly show or reflect the oppression that Indigenous people face.

The guiding question of "what does it mean to be a minority" and the social, economic, psychological, and national ramifications this question suggests were abundantly interesting to explore in class. Opening each class with brief recaps of our week/plans for weekends settled us into discussion-mode before we addressed the main material. Most assignments were very clear in requirements and due dates. Feedback and progression of projects was quite orderly. 

The course could be improved through providing targeted reading activities for homework; grammar activities were provided, but accompanying listening activities with this grammar would help solidify it all.

Strengths: course topics were interesting and engaging, conversations were extremely engaging and involved the entire class
Weaknesses: a relaxed focus on grammar as it was mainly assigned as homework lessons, so it became difficult to implement such skills into our writing
More notice about upcoming assignments and projects would be helpful, since they are a bit ambiguous on the syllabus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is a very good learning environment
No, I would not. It's anti-Indigenous in so many ways.
I'd highly recommend this course for its real-world relevance and impartation of empathy through the difficult topics of inequality and perseverance in spite of oppression which we explored.

Yes, the course topics were fantastic and really engaging while developing and learning Spanish. Spanish 140 is definitely my favorite Spanish level by far because the class engages in interesting conversations and great feedback.
